title: Index calculus algorithm
summary: In computational number theory, the index calculus algorithm is a probabilistic algorithm  for computing discrete logarithms. Dedicated to the discrete logarithm in ( Z / q Z ) âˆ— {\displaystyle (\mathbb {Z} /q\mathbb {Z} )^{*}} where q {\displaystyle q} is a prime, index calculus leads to a family of algorithms adapted to finite fields and to some families of elliptic curves. The algorithm collects relations among the discrete logarithms of small primes, computes them by a linear algebra procedure and finally expresses the desired discrete logarithm with respect to the discrete logarithms of small primes.
